docs.lead_paragraph: MICHELLE RIVERA was in a taxi in July 2004, heading to a pediatrician appointment for one of her young daughters, when she spotted her destiny. Plastered to a light pole was a flier advertising the inaugural Nike Women's Marathon in October. The race through San Francisco, which will be run for the second time on Sunday, features thousands of women running, either in a marathon or a half-marathon, and offers perks like prerace manicures, Ghirardelli chocolates handed out as energy boosters in the middle of the run, and a Tiffany necklace for each finisher.

headline.main: A Spirit of Sisterhood, From Start to Finish

docs.snippet: Women increasingly are training and racing together, as women's running groups have sprung up everywhere from Alaska to Florida.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is sometimes believed that the only current event most professional athletes know or care about is the status of their contract. Not in all cases, to be sure, and certainly not in the case of Wizards center Etan Thomas, who is entering his fifth season in the National Basketball Association. On Sept. 24, for one prominent example, the 6-foot-9, 256-pound Thomas, a graduate of Syracuse University with a degree in business management and a cascade of dreadlocks, spoke about his resistance to the war in Iraq and recited his poetry on the subject before hundreds of thousands of people at the Operation Ceasefire rally, held in the shadow of the Washington Monument. He read from his poem ''Bring Our Heroes Home'':

headline.main: A Center Fakes Right, Goes Left, Speaks Out

docs.snippet: Wizards center Etan Thomas, who is entering his fifth season in the N.B.A., uses poetry "to speak to young people."

docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (TNT) 2005 BLACK MOVIE AWARDS ''Crash,'' Paul Haggis's stunning drama about race relations in Southern California, was named outstanding motion picture at the ceremony, taped earlier this month in Los Angeles. Kimberly Elise (left) was named best actress for her role as a displaced wife in ''Diary of a Mad Black Woman.'' Terrence Howard was best actor for ''Hustle & Flow,'' in which he played a Memphis pimp having a midlife crisis. Sidney Poitier received the distinguished career achievement award. 8 P.M. (MTV) HARD ROCK LIVE: THE BRAVERY --This neo-post-punk group has been compared to the Strokes, the Killers, Modest Mouse and (strangely) the Go-Go's. Its hits include ''Fearless'' (''Too many fingers, too many thumbs/Something wicked this way comes''), ''Unconditional,'' ''Swollen Summer'' and ''An Honest Mistake.'' The concert was taped in Orlando, Fla. 9 P.M. (2) CRIMINAL MINDS -- A kidnapper Matthew Letscher) gets greedy. He has a United States attorney's daughter (Elizabeth Harnois) but now wants her twin sister too. Jason Gideon (Mandy Patinkin) and the behavioral analysis unit investigate. 9 P.M. (4) THE APPRENTICE: MARTHA STEWART -- Everybody makes salad dressing. 9 P.M. (7) LOST -- The people who captured Sawyer (Josh Holloway) and Jin (Daniel Dae Kim, right) force their prisoners to take them to their base camp. Michael (Harold Perrineau) has gone off on his own to search for his abducted son. 9 P.M. (13) DESTINATION AMERICA -- This four-part special examines the immigrant experience, past and present. 10 P.M. (Comedy Central) SOUTH PARK -- Season premiere. (So they say, but the series just had a season premiere in March.) There's no word on the new episode's topic, but last season's included a teacher's sex-change operation and a Teri Schiavo-reminiscent coma. 10 P.M. (7) INVASION -- Strange things continue to happen in a suddenly spooky Florida town in the days after the hurricane. Russell (Eddie Cibrian) is particularly suspicious about the sheriff's decision to shoot and kill a park ranger. 10:30 P.M. (Comedy Central) DRAWN TOGETHER -- Season premiere. Spanky Ham, Captain Hero, Foxxy Love, Wooldoor Sockbat and their toon housemates return in this animated parody of reality shows. Last season, characters dealt with weight problems, pregnancy scares, coming out, brain tumors and a billionaire named Bucky Bucks. ANITA GATES

docs.lead_paragraph: Christine Baze of Marblehead, Mass., was 31, married and hoping to start a family when she learned she had invasive cervical cancer and would need a total hysterectomy. Now 36 and childless but free of cancer, she is waging a campaign to keep what happened to her from afflicting other women. She created a Web site, popsmear.org, and the Yellow Umbrella Tour, a national concert tour, to spread the word.

headline.main: Getting to Know a Virus, and When It Can Kill

docs.snippet: Taking arms against the human papillomavirus, the leading cause of cervical cancer.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jennifer Garden has a tumor inside her head -- this much she understands. It will not kill her, she knows, but it has the power to make her miserable and steal her sight. Ms. Garden, 24, also has Medicaid -- sometimes, anyway. And there is much about it that she has just never understood -- the paperwork she gets in the mail, or why the system sometimes insures her and sometimes rejects her, or why she can see some doctors and not others.

headline.main: Trying to Get, and Keep, Care Under Medicaid; Navigating System Takes More Persistence Than Many Clients Have

docs.snippet: The saga of Jennifer Garden, who has a pituitary tumor, illustrates the idiosyncrasies of New York's vast, imperfect Medicaid system.

multimedia.caption: Struggling to Stay Insured

docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about a study finding that women with gum disease were more likely to have premature babies misstated the rate of premature births in the United States over the past two decades. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, it increased to 12.3 percent in 2003 from 9.4 percent in 1981; it did not hold steady near 10 percent.
docs.abstract: Correction of Oct 11 story on study linking pregnant women's gum disease with incidence of premature births regarding statistics on premature birth

docs.lead_paragraph: The police are searching for a Staten Island teenager and her newborn daughter after her aunt, who says the young woman has a history of suicide attempts, reported them missing on Friday. The girl, Tierra Vance, 17, was last seen wearing a black hooded sweatshirt, with her baby, Aleysha Aleyna Joi Perez, 6 weeks old, in a blue Graco baby stroller. Anyone with information is asked to call CrimeStoppers at 1-800-577-TIPS (1-800-577-8477).

headline.main: Police Searching for Teenager and Her Baby

docs.snippet: The police are searching for a teenager and her newborn daughter after her aunt. reported them missing.

byline.original: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ; John Holl contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: About a year ago, a girl was born in this working-class town and was promptly flung out of a third-floor window. She tumbled down a thin air shaft, naked, her umbilical cord still attached. Her head smashed into the concrete 31 feet below. She died instantly. And there she lay, unnamed, buried in a grave of garbage and cigarette packs. The story gets worse.

headline.main: Family Saga, And Skeleton, Uncovered; Two Births, and a Death, That Almost Escaped Notice

docs.snippet: A Sophoclean tale of incest, abuse and murder has shaken nearly everyone involved in West New York, N.J.

docs.lead_paragraph: Daria is the classic high school overachiever: straight A's, sports records and loads of other impressive credentials while still managing time for a cute new boyfriend. But the pressure to be perfect is slowly weighing her down, as are circumstances she can't change. Daria is a black girl adopted by a white family living in an overwhelmingly white state. Students in baggy jeans call her ''Sista,'' and blond girls ask if she's African. Her boyfriend must choose between his dream of studying poetry at college and his father's wish that he take over the struggling family farm.

headline.main: Teenagers Star in the Story of Their Lives, Painful Details and All

docs.abstract: Article on Voices Project, two-year undertaking by filmmaker Bess O'Brien and actress Abby Paige that chronicles lives of Vermont teenagers through interviews, artwork, poetry, musical and oral histories; culmination of project, musical starring 21 teenagers, is ending tour of 11 towns over six weekends; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The Voices Project is a two-year undertaking that chronicled the lives of Vermont teenagers through interviews, artwork, poetry, music and oral histories.

docs.lead_paragraph: Four weeks into the fall season, CBS continues to be wildly dominant on Thursdays. In Nielsen's estimates, the network won every half-hour among total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds with ''Survivor'' (17.57 million), ''CSI'' (27.38 million) and ''Without a Trace'' (20.55 million). Its average audience for the night, 21.83 million, more than doubled that of NBC, which was second place with 10.49 million. As the other networks are fighting for scraps in individual time slots, it is notable which shows are sinking and which solidifying. UPN's ''Everybody Hates Chris'' (6.13 million) drew its best ratings since its premiere, and managed to boost ''Love Inc.'' (3.94 million), which follows ''Everybody,'' the Chris Rock-inspired comedy. WB's ''Smallville'' (5.66 million) and ''Everwood'' (4.35 million) continued to carve out a good demographic niche for that channel's younger-skewing programming. On NBC, however, ''Joey'' (7.29 million) and ''ER'' (13.54 million) continued to play how low can you go. Both shows drew their lowest ratings ever among viewers 18 to 49 for original broadcasts. ABC's ''Alias'' (7.03 million) also continued to tank. ''Alias,'' the pregnancy spy show, led off a terrible night for the network, as ''Night Stalker'' (5.15 million) and ''Primetime Live'' (4.71 million) delivered minuscule ratings that placed ABC barely ahead of the smaller broadcasters WB and UPN. KATE AURTHUR

headline.main: Arts, Briefly; CBS Sweeps Thursday (Yet Again)
